<br>
<h2>December 15, 2021</h2>
<p><strong>The Omicron variant is spreading rapidly. What does it hold in store? Our analysis offers some scenarios to understand potential outcomes. We also look at the effects of boosters, the potential waning of vaccine efficacy, and new oral therapeutics.</strong></p>
<p><strong>On November 26, 2021,</strong> WHO reached deeper into the Greek alphabet to declare Omicron a new SARS-CoV-2 variant of concern.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ef60cd08-5209-4a47-a334-c1f5c6b70946"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ef60cd08-5209-4a47-a334-c1f5c6b70946" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Update on Omicron,” WHO, November 28, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The world’s reaction has been an unpleasant mixture of dread, fatigue, and déjà vu. Almost two years into a pandemic that has claimed more than five million lives and affected billions more, people everywhere are finding it hard to summon the energy for another chapter in the story.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="46b74198-2663-41d1-970f-d436b5148dea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="46b74198-2663-41d1-970f-d436b5148dea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Charlie Giattino et al., “Excess mortality during the coronavirus pandemic (COVID-19),” Our World in Data, December 7, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/pandemic-to-endemic-how-the-world-can-learn-to-live-with-covid-19">Endemicity remains the endpoint</a>. But at the time of writing, the Omicron variant is rewriting the timetable. Whether because Omicron is more infectious or has greater ability to evade the immune system, or both, it quickly became the dominant variant in South Africa.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="72460c10-22d9-4483-b1a5-50e32ec1ba35"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">52</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="72460c10-22d9-4483-b1a5-50e32ec1ba35" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Genomic epidemiology of novel coronavirus - Africa-focused subsampling,” Nextstrain, December 11, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  Data so far are mixed on the severity of the disease it causes: some early findings have pointed toward a mild clinical course, while other evidence has suggested that Omicron may lead to more frequent hospitalization in children than other variants do.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e3df1dec-1126-404a-b609-a2d87a182866"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">53</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e3df1dec-1126-404a-b609-a2d87a182866" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Implications of the further emergence and spread of the SARS CoV-2 B.1.1.529 variant of concern (Omicron) for the EU/EEA – first update,” European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), December 2, 2021; Loni Prinsloo, “Toddlers make up 10% of hospital cases in Omicron epicenter,” Bloomberg, November 29, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  We have <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/pandemic-to-endemic-how-the-world-can-learn-to-live-with-covid-19">written previously</a> about the transition to managing COVID-19 as an endemic disease and noted that a new variant was one of the greatest risks to timelines.</p>
<p>This article presents a new analysis of a range of scenarios based on the infectiousness, immune evasion, and severity of disease caused by the Omicron variant. Based on the evidence to date, we have posited a base-case scenario in which Omicron is about 25 percent more infectious, evades prior immunity to a greater degree (25 percent), and causes less severe disease, again by about 25 percent, all relative to Delta.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1ad65ccd-ace7-4aba-add1-040ca386241b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1ad65ccd-ace7-4aba-add1-040ca386241b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on analysis of all sources cited. Others have also advanced this view; for an example, see Grady McGregor, “Evidence mounts that Omicron is more infectious, less severe than Delta—but Fauci, other experts warn against premature optimism,” <em>Fortune</em>, December 6, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  Our analysis suggests that in the United States, this combination of characteristics would lead to Omicron replacing Delta as the dominant variant in the next few months and to a <em>higher peak burden of disease</em> than the country saw in the second half of 2021 (but likely below the peak reached in the winter of 2020–21).</p>
<p>This base-case scenario has the potential to place a severe strain on healthcare systems. The optimistic scenario would see a peak of disease burden close to that seen over the past six months, while the pessimistic would see a very significantly higher burden of disease than in the past six months. Note that in every scenario, our analysis indicates that hospitalizations will likely be higher in the next six months than they were in the past six months.</p>
<p>In any scenario for the future of the COVID-19 pandemic, much depends on the ways in which societies respond. Three levers are likely to be especially important, starting with the extent to which countries can effectively scale and make available new oral therapeutics with the potential to reduce the chance of progression to severe disease, and which are unlikely to be blunted by Omicron. Second, evidence is accumulating that booster doses are especially important for protecting against the Omicron variant; accelerating their rollout will help protect populations. And third, given public fatigue and the lessons of the past two years, finding the right combination of public-health measures will be critical.</p>
<h3>The Omicron variant</h3>
<p>Three main factors determine the real-world impact of any new SARS-CoV-2 variant: the extent to which it can evade the immunity developed by those who have been vaccinated or previously infected by other variants, its inherent infectiousness (often expressed as a higher basic reproduction number, or R0), and the severity of disease caused.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b9466a75-da2d-413a-8c46-3ad433a628b6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">55</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b9466a75-da2d-413a-8c46-3ad433a628b6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ewen Callaway and Heidi Ledford, “How bad is Omicron? What scientists know so far,” <em>Nature</em>, December 2, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  The first two factors combine to drive the number of cases, while the third determines the number of severe cases and deaths. For example, the Delta variant, which remains dominant in most of the world, was significantly more transmissible than previously circulating variants were, showed limited incremental evasion of immunity, and caused moderately more severe disease relative to other variants.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ae722c7f-d1fa-4878-8cd6-02add3748261"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ae722c7f-d1fa-4878-8cd6-02add3748261" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Delta variant: What we know about the science,” US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, August 26, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Early data paint a mixed picture of Omicron’s <em>evasion of vaccine-induced immunity</em>. The UK Health Security Agency recently summed up its view: “Early estimates of vaccine effectiveness (VE) against symptomatic infection find a significantly lower VE [against] Omicron infection compared to Delta infection. Nevertheless, a moderate to high [VE] of 70 to 75% is seen in the early period after a booster dose.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8cafd0a-1829-4e2f-b991-f998b7b39995"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">57</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8cafd0a-1829-4e2f-b991-f998b7b39995" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern and variants under investigation in England: Technical briefing 31,” UK Health Security Agency, December 13, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>There is still much more to learn—sample sizes in the new studies were small, antibody titers are an imperfect metric of immune protection, and major manufacturers are yet to release similar information. The response to Omicron may include both accelerating the rollout of booster doses of existing vaccines and developing new formulations better targeted to this variant. Companies have indicated that modified or new vaccines could be available in a few months, though the scale and global availability are unclear.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a8422c2c-e98f-4918-812a-51091e679b65"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">58</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a8422c2c-e98f-4918-812a-51091e679b65" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Pfizer and BioNTech provide update,” December 8, 2021; Khristopher J. Brooks, “CEOs and scientists on whether existing vaccines will work against Omicron,” CBS News, December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Regarding <em>evasion of natural immunity</em>, a preprint article from South Africa suggests a significantly higher chance of reinfection by Omicron relative to Delta or Beta.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d5f56480-3d97-48cd-8250-bf0a19a28e99"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d5f56480-3d97-48cd-8250-bf0a19a28e99" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Juliet R. C. Pulliam et al., “Increased risk of SARS-CoV-2 reinfection associated with emergence of the Omicron variant in South Africa,” medRxiv, December 2, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  Both the pace of case growth and the rapidly increasing share of Omicron among samples sequenced suggest that, through a combination of <em>greater infectiousness</em> and immune evasion, Omicron is spreading very quickly.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d313b015-103f-4d63-8cff-98efcb5966e2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">60</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d313b015-103f-4d63-8cff-98efcb5966e2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sarah Zhang, “Omicron’s explosive growth is a warning sign,” <em>Atlantic</em>, December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  If the experience of South Africa were to be repeated elsewhere, we could see a continued rapid increase in the number of COVID-19 cases as Omicron is established.</p>
<p>The question of <em>disease severity</em> is more complicated. Several clinicians in South Africa have noted the apparently mild presentation of Omicron cases.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ef7fde5c-9126-4dba-8f0b-3e54d0f41e89"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">61</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ef7fde5c-9126-4dba-8f0b-3e54d0f41e89" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Fareed Abdullah, “Tshwane district Omicron variant patient profile - early features,” South African Medical Research Council, December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  Further, the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) noted on December 12, 2021, that 776 cases were within its remit and “all cases for which there is available information on severity were either asymptomatic or mild. There have been no Omicron-related deaths reported thus far.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a2659adc-5543-4c5d-9fea-1d520bb78166"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">62</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a2659adc-5543-4c5d-9fea-1d520bb78166" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Epidemiological update: Omicron variant of concern (VOC) – data as of 12 December 2021 (12.00),” ECDC, December 12, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  On the other hand, ECDC also notes that it is too early to draw definitive conclusions on disease severity. The United Kingdom reported its first Omicron-related death on December 13, 2021, and some reports from South Africa suggest a potentially higher rate of hospitalization among young children than seen in previous waves of COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7252d4fc-effb-41c5-8ee7-c408a8147cf4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">63</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7252d4fc-effb-41c5-8ee7-c408a8147cf4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Becky Morton and Doug Faulkner, “Covid: First UK death recorded with Omicron variant,” BBC News, December 13, 2021; Mahsa Saeidi, “South Africa reports rise of omicron hospitalization of kids under 5, initial data shows,” WFLA, December 6, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>In the base-case scenario, US COVID-19-related hospitalizations could peak significantly higher in the next six months than in the past six months.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Each of these observed trends may change as sample sizes increase, confounding factors are considered, and the clinical course of disease plays out over time. The answers, when they arrive, will have important consequences for the months ahead. Given the uncertainty, we have built a set of scenarios describing potential outcomes measured by hospitalization rate. They are indexed on the recent Delta wave and show whether various potential combinations of infectiousness, immune evasion, and clinical severity are likely to lead to a higher or lower rate of COVID-19-related hospitalization.</p>
<p>The results of these scenarios for the United States are shown in Exhibit 1. Each of the three variables is an important driver of the outcomes. Evidence so far suggests that the Omicron variant, relative to Delta, is likely to be more infectious, show more immune evasion, and be less severe, on average. In the base case (25 percent more infectious; 25 percent greater immune evasion; 25 percent less severe disease), the COVID-19-related hospitalization rate in the United States could peak significantly higher in the next six months than in the past six. In the pessimistic scenarios, the peak number of hospitalizations for COVID-19 could be much higher in the next six months than in the past six months, whereas in the optimistic scenario, the number would be higher but similar to that seen in the second half of 2021, as waning immunity causes ongoing disease from a combination of the Delta and Omicron variants.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>The analysis is quite sensitive to public-health interventions and behaviors. Exhibit 1 assumes a US public-health response similar to that seen during the Delta wave. Exhibit 2 shows potential outcomes if <em>more stringent</em> public-health measures were to be employed in the United States; this could lead to a disease burden that is similar to or only moderately worse than seen in the past six months, depending on the characteristics of the virus. The exhibit also shows how much more stringent those measures would need to be to potentially prevent the disease burden from exceeding the burden of Delta. Our analysis accounts for waning immunity and suggests that even if Omicron were to have no impact, the next six months of Delta-driven disease in the United States could be about as severe as the past six months were.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/december%202021/svgz-pandemicupdate-ex2-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="If Omicron is more infectious than Delta, and society adopts significant new interventions, the increase in COVID-19 hospitalizations may be moderate." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/december%202021/svgz-pandemicupdate-ex2-final.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In the context of Omicron’s arrival and impending spread, three factors come to the forefront: the potential impact of new therapeutics in reducing hospitalizations and death, the criticality of boosters in the context of waning immunity, and clarity and consensus in public-health measures.</p>
<h3>Oral therapeutics</h3>
<p>The clinical management of COVID-19 has come a long way since the early days of the pandemic. The availability of effective monoclonal antibodies, dexamethasone, and other treatments and the use of nonpharmacological interventions, such as “proning,” have meaningfully increased the chances of survival for those with access to high-quality healthcare.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="21126ca9-be47-4ed7-8059-5bac7f1d7931"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">64</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="21126ca9-be47-4ed7-8059-5bac7f1d7931" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Stephan Ehrmann et al., “Awake prone positioning for COVID-19 acute hypoxaemic respiratory failure: A randomised, controlled, multinational, open-label meta-trial,” <em>Lancet: Respiratory Medicine</em>, December 1, 2021, Volume 9, Number 12; Peter Horby et al., “Dexamethasone in hospitalized patients with COVID-19,” <em>The New England Journal of Medicine</em>, February 25, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  Nevertheless, recent results from Merck–Ridgeback Biotherapeutics and Pfizer on their oral drugs molnupiravir and PAXLOVID, respectively (two antivirals, with different mechanisms of action<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="10bdd1c8-6f36-4f7f-bb33-54e7365c8018"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">65</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="10bdd1c8-6f36-4f7f-bb33-54e7365c8018" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Merck and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics provide update on results from MOVe-OUT study of molnupiravir, an investigational oral antiviral medicine, in at risk adults with mild-to-moderate COVID-19,” Merck, November 26, 2021; “Pfizer’s novel COVID-19 oral antiviral treatment candidate reduced risk of hospitalization or death by 89% in interim analysis of Phase 2/3 EPIC-HR study,” Pfizer, November 5, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>) represent a material advancement and increase the chance that the impact of the Omicron variant can be controlled. In its final study, Pfizer reported that PAXLOVID reduced risk of hospitalization or death by about 89 percent for high-risk patients and about 70 percent for standard-risk patients.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="76eb747f-5aa1-4980-bcfa-79cc0fadbf5f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">66</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="76eb747f-5aa1-4980-bcfa-79cc0fadbf5f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Pfizer announces additional Phase 2/3 study results confirming robust efficacy of novel COVID-19 oral antiviral treatment candidate in reducing risk of hospitalization or death,” December 14, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Oral therapeutics that significantly reduce the chance of progression to severe disease after symptom onset may enable a higher fraction of cases to be managed as outpatients. Such therapies are also easier to administer in lower-resourced regions than injected or infused treatments are. Further, manufacturing small molecules rapidly is faster than the process for monoclonal antibodies. The initial evidence indicates that the efficacy of these therapies is unlikely to be reduced by the mutations present in the Omicron variant.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e8eac387-b154-44a7-873a-cc21f1b93306"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">67</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e8eac387-b154-44a7-873a-cc21f1b93306" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jason Gale and John Lauerman, “How does Omicron challenge the treatments for Covid?,” Bloomberg, December 9, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>A number of questions and caveats remain. Data are not yet available on the drugs’ efficacy in vaccinated individuals. The drugs are more likely to be effective if taken within five days of symptom onset,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c21fc7d2-6f92-4708-871a-2826e5db91f5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">68</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c21fc7d2-6f92-4708-871a-2826e5db91f5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Merck and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics provide update,” November 26, 2021; “Pfizer’s novel COVID-19 oral antiviral treatment candidate,” November 5, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  requiring an efficient pathway from diagnosis to prescription and distribution. And some data inconsistencies have emerged—for example, it is unclear why molnupiravir’s efficacy in an interim analysis dropped in the final readout.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dc08c1d1-baa1-4f04-90cc-4e88dde638a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">69</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dc08c1d1-baa1-4f04-90cc-4e88dde638a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Merck and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics provide update,” November 26, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Other questions relate to the impact of the new therapeutics in blunting an Omicron-driven wave of disease. Can healthcare systems diagnose COVID-19 and distribute therapeutics fast enough for them to be effective? Will oral therapeutics be available quickly enough to blunt a potential Omicron surge in December 2021 and January 2022? How will drug–drug interactions with ritonavir be managed for PAXLOVID use? Can mutagenicity concerns in pregnant women for molnupiravir be managed to ensure patient safety while maximizing effective use of the drug? What role will antibody treatments play?</p>
<h3>Waning immunity and boosters</h3>
<p>The decline in the efficacy of COVID-19 vaccines over time and the benefits of booster doses have become much better understood over the past three months. While an initial course of all WHO-approved vaccines continues to provide strong protection against severe illness and death, the rate of breakthrough cases increases meaningfully as time passes, indicating that protection declines with time. For example, a July 2021 study of the Pfizer–BioNTech vaccine in Israel showed that in every age group studied, those who had been vaccinated by January 2021 were more likely to experience breakthrough infection than those who completed their initial course of vaccination two months later were.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="93dd69bb-97ea-454f-8791-b485e4e1009d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">70</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="93dd69bb-97ea-454f-8791-b485e4e1009d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yair Goldberg et al., “Waning immunity after the BNT162b2 vaccine in Israel,” <em>New England Journal of Medicine</em>, December 9, 2021, Volume 385.</span></span></span></a></span>  This general point appears to be especially true for the Omicron variant.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="72eca2e0-a623-46b0-a675-65a4b48218a6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">71</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="72eca2e0-a623-46b0-a675-65a4b48218a6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Pfizer and BioNTech provide update,” December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Evidence has also accumulated steadily about the benefit of booster doses, leading more countries to expand and accelerate their rollout.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a50f7df0-3acf-4d20-aede-43093c8e8c22"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">72</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a50f7df0-3acf-4d20-aede-43093c8e8c22" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Factbox: Countries weigh need for booster COVID-19 shots,” Reuters, December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  On October 21, 2021, Pfizer–BioNTech announced results from a randomized controlled trial of third doses of its COVID-19 vaccine; protection was restored to the levels seen in earlier trials after the second dose.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7acabcca-dbe9-46d3-93f8-213252c1cd97"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">73</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7acabcca-dbe9-46d3-93f8-213252c1cd97" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Pfizer and BioNTech announce Phase 3 trial data showing high efficacy of a booster dose of their COVID-19 vaccine,” Pfizer, October 21, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> More recent data, as previously described, highlight the benefits of booster doses in protecting against the Omicron variant.</p>
<p>WHO and others have raised important concerns about the appropriateness of high-income countries offering booster doses of COVID-19 vaccines while so many in the world have not received initial vaccination, but the benefits of a booster dose to an individual patient are increasingly clear.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b7ccc3cb-ddb1-4f71-92ee-42f47b86a656"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">74</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b7ccc3cb-ddb1-4f71-92ee-42f47b86a656" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“COVID-19 virtual press conference: 8 December 2021,” WHO, December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  The ongoing Delta-driven wave of cases in Europe has led a number of countries to accelerate their booster-dose rollout, with some discussing the timing of potential additional doses.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e64a7fa7-530c-46a7-9e65-f6102904669e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">75</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e64a7fa7-530c-46a7-9e65-f6102904669e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Alisa Odenheimer, “Israel is preparing for possible fourth Covid vaccine dose,” Bloomberg, September 12, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As countries transition over time to <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/pandemic-to-endemic-how-the-world-can-learn-to-live-with-covid-19">managing COVID-19 as an endemic disease</a>, the world may reach a long-term state of disease prevention similar to that seen with the flu, with annual or twice yearly booster doses. In the short term, an accelerated rollout of booster doses of COVID-19 vaccines is likely to be one of the best protections against an Omicron-fueled wave of the disease.</p>
<h3>Public-health measures</h3>
<p>Even before the emergence of Omicron, the past four months have seen the continued evolution of the public response to COVID-19. Debates have continued about the role of vaccine mandates, the use of vaccine passports, testing requirements, masks and mask mandates, and restrictions on gatherings. Societies are trying to find a new consensus through this transition, with some maintaining minimal public-health restrictions in the face of rising case counts and others reinstating more stringent measures. The emergence of Omicron led to tighter rules around travel in many countries, with some, such as England, also restricting domestic travel.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f80ede3b-a3c5-41a0-9759-769a47430ed3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">76</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f80ede3b-a3c5-41a0-9759-769a47430ed3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Prime Minister confirms move to plan B in England,” United Kingdom, December 8, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span>  Achieving some degree of consensus on public-health measures will likely be an important step toward controlling an Omicron-driven wave of disease.</p>
<hr>
<p>Omicron is a sobering reminder that SARS-CoV-2 has the advantage of rapid mutation and can produce new variants faster than anyone would like. We hope that this article offers a starting point to interpret the potential spread and severity of the disease it produces and the ways in which new therapeutics, booster doses of vaccines, and public-health measures will be important in limiting its impact.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>About the authors</strong></p>
<p><a href="/our-people/sarun-charumilind"><strong>Sarun Charumilind</strong></a> is a partner in McKinsey’s Philadelphia office, <a href="/our-people/matt-craven"><strong>Matt Craven</strong></a> is a partner in the Bay Area office, <strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-lamb">Jessica Lamb</a></strong> is a partner in the New Jersey office, <a href="/our-people/adam-sabow"><strong>Adam Sabow</strong></a> is a senior partner in the Chicago office, <a href="/our-people/shubham-singhal"><strong>Shubham Singhal</strong></a> is a senior partner in the Detroit office, and <a href="/our-people/matt-wilson"><strong>Matt Wilson</strong></a> is a senior partner in the New York office. </p>

<h2>August 23, 2021</h2>
<p><strong>This article updates our perspectives on when the coronavirus pandemic will end to reflect the latest information on vaccine rollout, variants of concern, and disease progression. Among high-income countries, cases caused by the Delta variant reversed the transition toward normalcy first in the United Kingdom, during June and July of 2021, and subsequently in the United States and elsewhere. Our own analysis supports the view of others that the Delta variant has effectively moved overall herd immunity out of reach in most countries for the time being. The United Kingdom’s experience nevertheless suggests that once a country has weathered a wave of Delta-driven cases, it may be able to resume the transition toward normalcy. Beyond that, a more realistic epidemiological endpoint might arrive not when herd immunity is achieved but when COVID-19 <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/pandemic-to-endemic-how-the-world-can-learn-to-live-with-covid-19">can be managed as an endemic disease</a>. The biggest overall risk would likely then be the emergence of a significant new variant.</strong></p>
<p><strong>Since the March installment</strong> in this series, many countries, including the United States, Canada, and those in Western Europe, experienced a measure of relief from the COVID-19 pandemic<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95eb50dd-367d-47e6-908c-a40c27de65cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">77</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95eb50dd-367d-47e6-908c-a40c27de65cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  “COVID data tracker weekly review,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, last accessed August 15, 2021, cdc.gov; <em>COVID-19 daily epidemiology update</em>, Government of Canada, updated August 18, 2021, health-infobase.canada.ca; Colleen Barry, Frank Jordans, and Nicole Winfield, “In time for summer, Europe sees dramatic fall in virus cases,” Associated Press, May 29, 2021, apnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span> when some locales embarked on the second-quarter transition toward normalcy that we previously discussed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="29e74197-bfbb-4423-a3e7-491d0c8ce61f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">78</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="29e74197-bfbb-4423-a3e7-491d0c8ce61f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   See our earlier perspectives, below, for definitions of normalcy and herd immunity. When we refer to herd-immunity timelines for a country, we mean the point at which the entire nation or a significant portion reaches herd immunity.</span></span></span></a></span> This progress was enabled by rapid vaccine rollout, with most Western European countries and Canada overcoming their slower starts during the first quarter of 2021 and passing the United States in the share of the
