class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Understanding the Delta variant</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The Delta variant</strong> of SARS-CoV-2, also called B1.617.2, emerged in late 2020 and has since spread rapidly around the world. It first caused major waves of disease in India and the United Kingdom and more recently triggered serious outbreaks in many other countries. The Delta variant has also tended to displace all other variants to become the dominant variant. Its behavior and effects, with respect to several key measurable traits, are as follows<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c2e8b64f-6031-46e7-b3a2-56640f3082c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c2e8b64f-6031-46e7-b3a2-56640f3082c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  “Delta variant: What we know about the science,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, updated August 19, 2021, cdc.gov; Yasmeen Abutaleb, Joel Achenbach, and Carolyn Y. Johnson, “‘The war has changed’: Internal CDC document urges new messaging, warns delta infections likely more severe,” <em>Washington Post</em>, July 29, 2021, washingtonpost.com; Apoorva Mandavilli, “CDC internal report calls Delta variant as contagious as chickenpox,” <em>New York Times</em>, July 30, 2021, nytimes.com; Michaeleen Doucleff, “The Delta variant isn’t as contagious as chickenpox. But it’s still highly contagious,” NPR, August 11, 2021, npr.org; Josh Ulick and Alberto Cervantes, “What makes the Delta variant of Covid-19 so dangerous for unvaccinated people,” <em>Wall Street Journal</em>, July 30, 2021, wsj.com.</span></span></span></a></span>: </p>
<p><strong>Transmissibility</strong>—Delta is significantly more transmissible than either the ancestral COVID-19 variant or other variants. The R0 value for the Delta variant (the number of people who can be expected to contract a disease by a single infected person) has been estimated at 5 to 8 by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Limited evidence also suggests that vaccinated individuals who are infected by the Delta variant can transmit it to others as efficiently as unvaccinated people do. </p>
<p><strong>Fatality</strong>—Limited evidence suggests that the case fatality ratio (the proportion of deaths among confirmed cases) of the Delta variant is roughly one and a half to two times greater than that of ancestral COVID-19. </p>
<p><strong>Immunity</strong>—While data are still being gathered and existing evidence is not fully consistent, the general picture is that full vaccination with the vaccines used in Western countries generally provides strong protection against serious illness caused by the Delta variant. Evidence of protection against infection is more mixed, with a recent preprint suggesting that full vaccination provides only moderate protection.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fbf11695-549e-4bc4-8181-9e9a980378a6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fbf11695-549e-4bc4-8181-9e9a980378a6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  Arjun Puranik et al., “Comparison of two highly-effective mRNA vaccines for COVID-19 during periods of Alpha and Delta variant prevalence,” medRxiv, August 8, 2021, medrxiv.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Prior natural infection with a different variant appears to provide only partial protection against Delta.</p>
<p>SARS-CoV-2 continues to mutate, and so new variants are likely to emerge. Their behavior and effects, regarding these characteristics, will determine the extent to which they displace existing variants and affect the prospects for reaching the end of the pandemic. </p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Among high-income countries, cases caused by the Delta variant reversed the transition toward normalcy first in the United Kingdom, where a summertime surge of cases led authorities to delay lifting public-health restrictions, and more recently in the United States and elsewhere. The Delta variant increases the short-term burden of disease, causing more cases, hospitalizations, and deaths.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="28fae633-7522-4870-944b-106e5b23bc37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">82</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="28fae633-7522-4870-944b-106e5b23bc37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  “Delta variant: What we know about the science,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, August 6, 2021, cdc.gov; Yasmeen Abutaleb, Joel Achenbach, and Carolyn Y. Johnson, “‘The war has changed’: Internal CDC document urges new messaging, warns delta infections likely more severe,” <em>Washington Post</em>, July 29, 2021, washingtonpost.com; Apoorva Mandavilli, “CDC internal report calls Delta variant as contagious as chickenpox,” <em>New York Times</em>, July 30, 2021, nytimes.com; Michaeleen Doucleff, “The Delta variant isn’t as contagious as chickenpox. But it’s still highly contagious,” NPR, August 11, 2021, npr.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Delta’s high transmissibility also makes herd immunity harder to achieve: a larger fraction of a given population must be immune to keep Delta from spreading within that population (see sidebar, “Understanding the Delta variant”). Our own analysis supports the view of others that the Delta variant has effectively moved herd immunity out of reach in most countries for now,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27ba9050-5813-4788-854f-fd2f796f8bfa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">83</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27ba9050-5813-4788-854f-fd2f796f8bfa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Christie Aschwanden, “Five reasons why COVID herd immunity is probably impossible,” <em>Nature</em>, March 18, 2021, nature.com.</span></span></span></a></span> although some regions may come close to it. </p>
<p>While the vaccines used in Western countries remain highly effective at preventing severe disease due to COVID-19, recent data from Israel, the United Kingdom, and the United States have raised new questions about the ability of these vaccines to prevent infection from the Delta variant.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="be55e94d-d0e1-4f8c-badf-e2361083ac70"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">84</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="be55e94d-d0e1-4f8c-badf-e2361083ac70" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Arjun Puranik et al., “Comparison of two highly-effective mRNA vaccines for COVID-19 during periods of Alpha and Delta variant prevalence,” medRxiv, August 8, 2021, medrxiv.org; Alistair Smout, “English study finds 50-60% reduced risk of COVID for double-vaccinated,” Reuters, August 3, 2021, reuters.com; Berkeley Lovelace Jr., “Israel says Pfizer Covid vaccine is just 39% effective as delta spreads, but still prevents severe illness,” CNBC, July 23, 2021, cnbc.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Serial blood tests suggest that immunity may wane relatively quickly. This has prompted some high-income countries to start offering booster doses to high-risk populations or planning for their rollout.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="58acad8c-267e-4b63-825c-507f3e4737c2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">85</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="58acad8c-267e-4b63-825c-507f3e4737c2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Kate Brady and Reis Thebault, “Europe to give covid booster shots as ‘half the world is still starving’ for vaccines,” <em>Washington Post</em>, August 4, 2021, washingtonpost.com; Sharon LaFraniere, “U.S. to advise boosters for most Americans 8 months after vaccination,” <em>New York Times</em>, August 16, 2021, nytimes.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Data from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also suggest that vaccinated people who become infected with the Delta variant may transmit it efficiently.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="293726ab-6a1c-4fcb-86d9-b8865ac6656d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">86</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="293726ab-6a1c-4fcb-86d9-b8865ac6656d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> “Delta variant,” August 6, 2021; “‘The war has changed’: Internal CDC document,” July 29, 2021; “CDC internal report,” July 30, 2021; “The Delta variant isn’t as contagious,” August 11, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>These events and findings have raised new questions about when the pandemic will end. The United Kingdom’s experience nevertheless suggests that once a country has weathered a Delta-driven wave of cases, it may be able to relax public-health measures and resume the transition toward normalcy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="93abdc50-4fa5-4e2f-8abc-477d84cc9d7d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">87</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="93abdc50-4fa5-4e2f-8abc-477d84cc9d7d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Sarah Zhang, “Watch the U.K. to understand Delta,” <em>Atlantic</em>, August 3, 2021, theatlantic.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Beyond that, a more realistic epidemiological endpoint might arrive not when herd immunity is achieved but when countries are able to control the burden of COVID-19 enough that it can be managed as an endemic disease. The biggest risk to a country’s ability to do this would likely then be the emergence of a new variant that is more transmissible, more liable to cause hospitalizations and deaths, or more capable of infecting people who have been vaccinated. </p>
<p>Raising vaccination rates will be essential to achieving a transition toward normalcy. Vaccine hesitancy, however, has proven to be a persistent challenge, both to preventing the spread of the Delta variant and to reaching herd immunity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f340db5-fb42-48ca-a9f6-b329fb95d064"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">88</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f340db5-fb42-48ca-a9f6-b329fb95d064" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   “COVID-19 Consumer Healthcare Insights,” June 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The US Food and Drug Administration has now fully approved Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine, and other full approvals may follow soon, which could help increase vaccination rates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ed7be4d9-9fe9-43d9-af74-7a3053dadecf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">89</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ed7be4d9-9fe9-43d9-af74-7a3053dadecf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> “FDA approves first COVID-19 vaccine,” US Food and Drug Administration news release, August 23, 2021, fda.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> Vaccines are also likely to be made available to children in the coming months,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6411c941-09e4-41c5-ae4e-bebb6518a3e5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">90</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6411c941-09e4-41c5-ae4e-bebb6518a3e5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Samantha Artiga, Jennifer Kates, Kendal Orgera, and Jennifer Tolbert, “The next stage of COVID-19 vaccine roll-out in United States: Children under 12,” Kaiser Family Foundation, July 30, 2021, kff.org.</span></span></span></a></span> making it possible to protect a group that comprises a significant share of the population in some countries. </p>
<p>In this article, we review developments since our March update, offer a perspective on the situation and evidence as of this writing, and present our scenario-based analysis of when a transition toward normalcy could occur. </p>
<h3>Even without herd immunity, a transition toward normalcy is possible</h3>
<p>We have written previously about two endpoints for the COVID-19 pandemic: a transition toward normalcy, and herd immunity. The transition would gradually normalize aspects of social and economic life, with some public-health measures remaining in effect as people gradually resume prepandemic activities. Many high-income countries did begin such a transition toward normalcy during the second quarter of this year, only to be hit with a new wave of cases caused by the Delta variant and exacerbated by vaccine hesitancy. </p>
<p>Indeed, our scenario analysis suggests that the United States, Canada, and many European countries would likely have reached herd immunity by now if they had faced only the ancestral SARS-CoV-2 virus and if a high percentage of those eligible to receive the vaccine had chosen to take it. But as the more infectious Delta variant becomes more prevalent within a population, more people within that population must be vaccinated before herd immunity can be achieved (Exhibit 1). </p>
<!-- -->
<p>Vaccine hesitancy makes it all the more difficult to reach the population-wide vaccination level rates that confer herd immunity. Researchers are learning more about differences among individuals’ attitudes, which include both “cautious” and “unlikely to be vaccinated.” <span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c4e9345e-991b-4023-a110-c30e2b80310d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">91</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c4e9345e-991b-4023-a110-c30e2b80310d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   “COVID-19 Consumer Healthcare Insights,” June 2021. </span></span></span></a></span> Meanwhile, social tolerance for vaccination incentives and mandates appears to be growing, with more European locations adopting vaccination passes<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a132e103-509f-4b34-bcf2-0b3efbfb9e37"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">92</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a132e103-509f-4b34-bcf2-0b3efbfb9e37" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   EU Digital COVID Certificate, European Commission, accessed August 15, 2021, ec.europa.eu; “Covid passports: How do they work around the world?,” BBC News, July 26, 2021, bbc.com.</span></span></span></a></span> and more large employers in the United States implementing vaccine mandates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="928ec9a2-2378-427a-8674-c95860a00ad2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">93</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="928ec9a2-2378-427a-8674-c95860a00ad2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Leslie Josephs and Robert Towey, “Covid vaccine mandates sweep across corporate America as delta variant spurs action,” CNBC, August 9, 2021, cnbc.com; Alexis Benveniste, “From offices to restaurants, companies are requiring proof of vaccination,” CNN, August 4, 2021, cnn.com.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>While it now appears unlikely that large countries will reach overall herd immunity (though some areas might), developments in the United Kingdom during the past few months may help illustrate the prospects for Western countries to transition back toward normalcy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ec56c721-58a5-4fc1-8365-c0280ba77478"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">94</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ec56c721-58a5-4fc1-8365-c0280ba77478" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  “Watch the U.K. to understand Delta,” August 2021; Grady McGregor, Sophie Mellor, and Biman Mukherji, “Delta waves in India and the U.K. have already receded. Could the same happen in the U.S.?,” <em>Fortune</em>, August 3, 2021, fortune.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Having suffered a wave of cases caused by the Delta variant during June and the first few weeks of July, the country delayed plans to ease many public-health restrictions and eventually did so on July 19, though expansive testing and genomic surveillance remain in place. UK case counts may fluctuate and targeted public-health measures may be reinstated, but our scenario analysis suggests that the country’s renewed transition toward normalcy is likely to continue unless a significant new variant emerges. </p>
<p>The United States, Canada, and much of the European Union are now in the throes of a Delta-driven wave of cases.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="abcc57a8-6dd6-424a-b973-006ac7bf093e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">95</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="abcc57a8-6dd6-424a-b973-006ac7bf093e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> “COVID data tracker weekly review,” accessed August 15, 2021; <em>COVID-19 daily epidemiology update</em>, August 18, 2021; “SARS-COV-2 Delta variant now dominant in much of the European Region and efforts must be reinforced to prevent transmission, warn WHO/Europe and ECDC,” European Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, July 23, 2021, ecdc.europa.eu; Ceylan Yeginsu, “The new reality of a European trip: ‘Things are going to change,’” <em>New York Times</em>, July 30, 2021, nytimes.com.
    </span></span></span></a></span> While each country’s situation is different, most have again enacted public-health restrictions, thus reversing their transitions toward normalcy. The trajectory of the epidemic remains uncertain, but the United Kingdom’s experience and estimates of total immunity suggest that many of these countries are likely to see new cases peak late in the third quarter or early in the fourth quarter of 2021. As cases decline, our analysis suggests that the United States, Canada, and the European Union could restart the transition toward normalcy as early as the fourth quarter of 2021, provided that the vaccines used in these countries continue to be effective at preventing severe cases of COVID-19. Allowing for the risk of another new variant and the compound societal risk of a high burden of influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and other winter respiratory diseases, the question for these countries will be whether they manage to arrive at a different epidemiological endpoint, as we discuss next. </p>
<h3> Endemic COVID-19 may be a more realistic endpoint than herd immunity</h3>
<p>We have previously written about herd immunity as a likely epidemiological endpoint for some countries, but the Delta variant has put this out of reach in the short term. Instead, it is most likely as of now that countries will reach an alternative epidemiological endpoint, where COVID-19 becomes endemic and societies decide—much as they have with respect to influenza and other diseases—that the ongoing burden of disease is low enough that COVID-19 can be managed as a constant threat rather than an exceptional one requiring society-defining interventions. One step toward this endpoint could be shifting the focus of public-health efforts from managing case counts to managing severe illnesses and deaths. Singapore’s government has announced that it will make this shift, and more countries may follow its lead.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f665bb2-e064-45a8-9b48-a3b889a74c27"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">96</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f665bb2-e064-45a8-9b48-a3b889a74c27" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">   Niharika Mandhana, “From pandemic to endemic, Singapore creates model for living with Covid-19,” <em>Wall Street Journal</em>, July 1, 2021, wsj.com.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<p>Other authors have compared the burden of COVID-19 with that of other diseases, such as influenza, as a way to understand when endemicity might occur.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8a446a81-2f97-48b3-afcd-8aa40346b564"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">97</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8a446a81-2f97-48b3-afcd-8aa40346b564" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Alexis Madrigal, “A simple rule of thumb for knowing when the pandemic is over,” <em>Atlantic</em>, February 23, 2021, theatlantic.com; Stephen M. Kissler et al., “Projecting the transmission dynamics of SARS-C0V-2 through the postpandemic period,” <em>Science</em>, May 22, 2020, Volume 368, Issue 6493, pp. 860–68, science.sciencemag.org; William A. Haseltine, “Covid-19 could end up like the flu—or worse,” <em>Forbes</em>, February 11, 2021, forbes.com; Helen Branswell, “How the Covid pandemic ends: Scientists look to the past to see the future,” STAT, May 19, 2021, statnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span> In the United States, COVID-19 hospitalization and mortality rates in June and July were nearing the ten-year average rates for influenza but have since risen. Today, the burden of disease caused by COVID-19 in vaccinated people in the United States is similar to or lower than the average burden of influenza over the last decade, while the risks from COVID-19 to unvaccinated people are significantly higher (Exhibit 2). This comparison should be qualified, insofar as the burden of COVID-19 is dynamic, currently increasing, and uneven geographically. It nevertheless helps illustrate the relative threat posed by the two diseases. </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/archive%20%20%20not%20live/hss/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/august%202021/svgz-pandemicend-ex2-821.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/archive%20%20%20not%20live/hss/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/august%202021/svgz-pandemicend-ex2-821.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Countries experiencing a Delta-driven wave of cases may be more likely to begin managing COVID-19 as an endemic disease after cases go into decline.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="593021bf-68fb-4019-8f1b-699975aca77b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">98</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="593021bf-68fb-4019-8f1b-699975aca77b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“From pandemic to endemic,” July 1, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The United Kingdom appears to be making this shift now (though cases there were increasing as of this writing). For the United States and the European Union, scenario analysis suggests that the shift may begin in the fourth quarter of 2021 and continue into early 2022 (Exhibit 3). As it progresses, countries would likely achieve high levels of protection against hospitalization and death as a result of further vaccination efforts (which may be accelerated by fear of the Delta variant) and natural immunity from prior infection. In addition, boosters, full approval of vaccines (rather than emergency-use authorization), authorization of vaccines for children, and a continuation of the trend toward employer and government mandates and incentives for vaccination are all likely to increase immunity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5abe194d-283d-41b1-a73f-ad081663dffc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">99</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5abe194d-283d-41b1-a73f-ad081663dffc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> “Q&A: When might the coronavirus vaccines get full approval?,” August 2, 2021; “Covid vaccine mandates,” August 9, 2021; “From offices to restaurants,” August 4, 2021.
    </span></span></span></a></span> </p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/archive%20%20%20not%20live/hss/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/august%202021/svgz-pandemicend-ex3-821.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/archive%20%20%20not%20live/hss/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/august%202021/svgz-pandemicend-ex3-821.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Our scenario modeling suggests that although the resulting level of population immunity may not be high enough to achieve herd protection, it would still protect a substantial portion of the population. Most serious cases of COVID-19 would occur in unvaccinated people. Flare-ups and localized epidemics would happen while COVID-19 is managed as an endemic disease, but scenario modeling suggests that these may have less of an effect on the whole of society than the waves seen to date. Booster vaccinations will be important in maintaining immunity levels over time.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="edecfdc6-6300-43d2-9476-1d41f280e275"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">100</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="edecfdc6-6300-43d2-9476-1d41f280e275" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> “US to advise boosters,” August 16, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> A new variant that substantially evades existing immunity would remain the biggest overall risk. </p>
<h3> Countries have varying prospects for reaching the end of the pandemic</h3>
<p>Here, we offer a broader geographic view, comparing the current state as of the time of publishing in countries around the world. Our analysis suggests that countries fall into three general groups (within which national conditions can vary to some extent): </p>
<p><em><strong>1. High-vaccination countries.</strong></em> These countries, primarily in North America and Western Europe, are the ones discussed above. </p>
<p><strong><em>2. Case controllers.</em></strong> This group includes countries such as Singapore that have been most successful in limiting mortality associated with COVID-19 to date.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a010ad61-ac2f-4e7f-aa27-d4153e30aca5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">101</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a010ad61-ac2f-4e7f-aa27-d4153e30aca5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“From pandemic to endemic,” July 1, 2021; Renju Jose, “Sydney daily COVID-19 cases hit record high, more troops to enforce lockdown,” Reuters, August 13, 2021, reuters.com.</span></span></span></a></span> They have typically maintained tight border restrictions and a strong public-health response to imported cases. Their residents have mostly enjoyed long periods of relative normalcy without public-health restrictions, aside from limits on international travel. Some countries in this group, such as Australia, have recently faced a Delta-driven surge in cases, but in absolute terms the burden of disease remains low relative to other countries. Unless these countries choose to maintain their border restrictions (such as hotel-based quarantine) indefinitely, they might accept the risk of endemic COVID-19 after governments determine that a sufficient portion of the population is vaccinated.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a242f515-f34e-4958-907b-1563749682ae"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">102</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a242f515-f34e-4958-907b-1563749682ae" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  Salma Khalik, “Moving from Covid-19 pandemic to endemic: Singapore’s strategy and how it can unfold,” <em>Straits Times</em>, July 3, 2021, straitstimes.com; Peter Collignon, “Australia must eventually face reality: Live with Covid or become a hermit nation,” <em>Guardian</em>, June 15, 2021, theguardian.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The pace of vaccine rollout varies among the countries, but in many cases reopening of borders may not begin until 2022, dependent in part on public-health outcomes for countries in other groups.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b28cc2a-4b92-42db-9eae-05532613c0c3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">103</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b28cc2a-4b92-42db-9eae-05532613c0c3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"> Frances Mao, “‘Fortress Australia’: Why calls to open up borders are meeting resistance,” BBC News, May 26, 2021, bbc.com; Meena Thiruvengadam, “New Zealand to keep its borders closed through the end of 2021,” <em>Travel and Leisure</em>, August 12, 2021, travelandleisure.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The shift from a zero-COVID-19 goal to an endemic, low-burden goal may be challenging for some countries. </p>
<p><em><strong>3. At-risk countries.</strong></em> Mainly comprising most lower-income and many middle-income countries, this is a group of nations that have not yet gained access to enough vaccine doses to cover a large portion of their populations. Estimates of their overall immunity remain low enough that there is still a risk of significant waves of disease. Recent projections suggest that it is likely to take until late 2022 or early 2023 for these countries to achieve high vaccine coverage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c6a50db4-536a-4c7e-86eb-34958c90b1d8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">104</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c6a50db4-536a-4c7e-86eb-34958c90b1d8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  Sara Jerving, “Africa not on track for 10% COVID-19 vaccination rate by end of year,” Devex, July 30, 2021, devex.com; “Over half a billion COVID-19 vaccine doses administered in WHO South-East Asia Region as countries scale up vaccination efforts,” World Health Organization, August 6, 2021, who.int.</span></span></span></a></span> The possible time frame for them to manage COVID-19 as an endemic disease is less clear. </p>
<p>Globally and nationally, the epidemiological and public-health situation remains dynamic, and the prospects for each country group are subject to uncertainty. Factors that could influence actual outcomes include: </p>
<ul>
    <li>the potential for new variants to emerge (for example, a variant that evades vaccine-mediated immunity to the extent that it frequently causes severe disease in the vaccinated and spreads widely would likely have the most significant effect on any country’s prospects for reaching the end of the pandemic) </li>
    <li>further evidence of waning natural and vaccine-mediated immunity over time, and challenges with rolling out vaccine boosters quickly enough to maintain immunity</li>
    <li>further challenges with vaccine manufacturing or global rollout</li>
    <li>changes in the ways that countries define an acceptable burden of disease (for example, setting different targets for disease burden in vaccinated and unvaccinated populations)</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The surge of COVID-19 cases resulting from the spread of the Delta variant and from vaccine hesitancy brought a sudden, tragic end to the transition toward normalcy that some countries had begun to make. But the United Kingdom’s experience indicates that a transition toward normalcy may yet be possible before long, at least in countries where the vaccine rollout is well under way. Their task will be determining what burden of disease is low enough to warrant lifting of public-health restrictions, and how to manage the public-health impacts of endemic COVID-19. In countries where vaccination rates remain low, the prospects for ending the pandemic remain largely tied to the availability and administration of additional doses. Expanding the international vaccine rollout remains essential to achieving a postpandemic sense of normalcy worldwide. </p>
<hr>
<p><strong>About the authors</strong></p>
<p><a href="/our-people/sarun-charumilind"><strong>Sarun Charumilind</strong></a> is a partner in McKinsey’s Philadelphia office, <a href="/our-people/matt-craven"><strong>Matt Craven</strong></a> is a partner in the Silicon Valley office, <strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-lamb">Jessica Lamb</a></strong> is a partner in the New Jersey office, <a href="/our-people/adam-sabow"><strong>Adam Sabow</strong></a> is a senior partner in the Chicago office, <a href="/our-people/shubham-singhal"><strong>Shubham Singhal</strong></a> is a senior partner in the Detroit office, and <a href="/our-people/matt-wilson"><strong>Matt Wilson</strong></a> is a senior partner in the New York office. </p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Xavier Azcue, Marie-Renée B-Lajoie, Andrew Doy, Bruce Jia, and Roxana Pamfil for their contributions to this article.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Josh Rosenfield, an executive editor in the New York office.</p>
<hr>
<br>
<br>
<h2>March 26, 2021</h2>
<p><strong>The fall in COVID-19 cases</strong> across much of the world over the past ten weeks signals a new dawn in the fight against the disease. Vaccines are proving effective and rapidly scaling, bending the curve in many geographies. This is a fragile dawn, however, with transmission and deaths still high, unequal access to vaccines, and variants of concern threatening to undo progress to date.</p>
<p>The trajectory of UK and US cases has enabled the beginnings of a transition toward normalcy,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a94d39a8-7a6d-4dad-8cbf-b87336b5985b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">105</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a94d39a8-7a6d-4dad-8cbf-b87336b5985b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See our earlier perspectives, below, for definitions of normalcy and herd immunity. When we refer to herd-immunity timelines for a country, we mean the point at which the entire nation or a significant portion reaches herd immunity. </span></span></span></a></span> the first and more important of the pandemic’s two endpoints. We expect this transition to continue in the second quarter of 2021 and will likely see many aspects of social and economic life return to the prepandemic normal, consistent with UK Prime Minister Johnson’s staged reopening plan for the United Kingdom<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2d0c9347-3249-4398-b51c-971fcb2730ff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">106</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2d0c9347-3249-4398-b51c-971fcb2730ff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Lockdown: Boris Johnson unveils plan to end England restrictions by 21 June,” BBC, February 22, 2021, bbc.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  and US President Biden’s goal of a normal Independence Day.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="20242aae-225f-4351-af84-f5da0ee425fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">107</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="20242aae-225f-4351-af84-f5da0ee425fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Covid pandemic: Biden eyes 4 July as ‘Independence Day’ from virus,” BBC, March 12, 2021, bbc.com.</span></span></span></a></span> We are more confident in this timeline for the United Kingdom than for the United States, given that the first has already experienced a wave driven by a more infectious variant, whereas the latter could still face one. Parts of the European Union have recently faced setbacks: fewer doses in arms than in the United Kingdom or United States, a new wave of cases, and new lockdowns. A transition toward normalcy is mostly likely in Europe during the late second or third quarter of 2021. The timing will probably vary by country, depending on accelerating vaccine supplies, the impact of vaccinations on hospitalization rates, and the occurrence (or not) of new waves driven by new variants.</p>
<p>Herd immunity, the second endpoint, is most likely in the third quarter for the United Kingdom and the United States and in the fourth quarter for the European Union, with the difference driven by a more limited vaccine availability in the European Union. However, the risks to these timelines are real—herd immunity may not be achieved by the end of the year if vaccine hesitancy is high, if countries experience disruptions in vaccine supply, or if a variant that renders existing vaccines less effective spreads widely. And herd immunity may look different in different parts of the world, ranging from strong nationwide or regional protection to temporary or oscillating immunity to some countries not reaching herd immunity over the medium term. </p>
<p>In this article, we’ll review the developments since our last perspective (January 21), offer an outlook for each of the three geographies, assess risks, and outline what the end of the pandemic might look like.</p>
<h3>Recent developments and their impact on timelines</h3>
<p>The past month or two have seen seven important developments:</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Vaccines work. </em>We have growing evidence that vaccines are effective, as real-world data from Israel and the United Kingdom validate the clinical-trial results by showing a sharp reduction in hospitalizations and deaths.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b1ba26cb-8b38-433a-8a72-696552112f2e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">108</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b1ba26cb-8b38-433a-8a72-696552112f2e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jacqui Wise, “Covid-19: Pfizer BioNTech vaccine reduced cases by 94% in Israel, shows peer reviewed study,” BMJ, February 25, 2021, Volume 372, Number 8282 bmj.com; Benjamin Mueller, “Vaccines sharply cut coronavirus hospitalization, U.K. studies show,” <em>New York Times,</em> February 22, 2021, nytimes.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  Emerging evidence also indicates that vaccines likely reduce transmission considerably, though not to the same degree that they prevent severe disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea87be6b-9ca3-4a9b-91e8-91da8b561969"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">109</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea87be6b-9ca3-4a9b-91e8-91da8b561969" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Science brief: Background rationale and evidence for public health recommendations for fully vaccinated people,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, last updated March 8, 2021, cdc.gov.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>The vaccine rollout is improving.</em> Massive inoculation programs have accelerated, especially in the United Kingdom. As of March 15, the United Kingdom has administered 39 doses per 100 people in the total population; the corresponding figures for the United States and the European Union are 33 and 12 per 100, respectively.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2343ad25-ba2b-4644-a6c9-4d006e654f7b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">110</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2343ad25-ba2b-4644-a6c9-4d006e654f7b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Hannah Ritchie et al., “Coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccinations,” Our World in Data, last accessed March 15, 2021, ourworldindata.org. </span></span></span></a></span>  Just as important: sentiment about vaccine adoption is improving.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c5107409-5fe4-41b8-848c-d2d5983d5c52"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">111</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c5107409-5fe4-41b8-848c-d2d5983d5c52" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Science brief,” last updated March 8, 2021; Matthew Smith, “Europe is becoming more pro-vaccine,” YouGov, January 22, 2021, yougov.co.uk.</span></span></span></a></span> </li>
    <li><em>More vaccines are coming.</em> Johnson & Johnson’s one-shot vaccine appears to be highly effective against severe COVID-19 and received Emergency Use Authorization in the United States on February 27.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a3583278-8bf9-4701-8f38-544dc394b08f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">112</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a3583278-8bf9-4701-8f38-544dc394b08f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“FDA issues Emergency Use Authorization for third COVID-19 vaccine,” US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), February 27, 2021, fda.gov.</span></span></span></a></span>  Novavax’s vaccine is now in Phase III trials; preliminary results suggest it was highly effective in the United Kingdom but less so in South Africa.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b570acfc-a0db-46f0-8a8e-19dc813f1105"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">113</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b570acfc-a0db-46f0-8a8e-19dc813f1105" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nick Paul Taylor, “Novavax COVID-19 vaccine 90% efficacious in phase 3, but protection plummets against one variant,” Fierce Biotech, January 29, 2021, fiercebiotech.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  All of that makes it increasingly clear that the United Kingdom and the United States will have enough doses to vaccinate all adults by the end of the second quarter, and Europe should achieve the same milestone by the end of the third quarter, assuming no major vaccines are withdrawn. Further, vaccine trials on children aged 12 and up are well underway, and new trials on babies and children six months and older raise the possibility of pediatric vaccination, which would add to the population that could potentially contribute to herd immunity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3a768504-fccc-4751-ad58-0fc39ce97eac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">114</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3a768504-fccc-4751-ad58-0fc39ce97eac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Peter Loftus, “Moderna is testing its COVID-19 vaccine on young children,” <em>The Wall Street Journal,</em> March 16, 2021, wsj.com. </span></span></span></a></span> </li>
    <li><em>Therapeutics are poised to make more of a difference.</em> A new wave of COVID-19 therapeutics, including those from Eli Lilly,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c35b4c53-1086-4f6b-8f89-8b86f1f92131"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">115</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c35b4c53-1086-4f6b-8f89-8b86f1f92131" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Lilly's bamlanivimab and etesevimab together reduced hospitalizations and death in Phase 3 trial for early COVID-19,” Lilly, March 10, 2021, lilly.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  Merck–Ridgeback,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ad9c7a18-ee8e-432b-981a-8a58bdac7711"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">116</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ad9c7a18-ee8e-432b-981a-8a58bdac7711" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ben Adams, “Merck has better luck with 2nd COVID-19 drug attempt as it sees a positive in early molnupiravir data,” Fierce Biotech, March 8, 2021, fiercebiotech.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  and Vir Biotechnology,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="29bae243-c967-4d3d-abf1-9902e9dad4ac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">117</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="29bae243-c967-4d3d-abf1-9902e9dad4ac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mark Terry, “Vir Bio’s COVID-19 antibody therapy could be great, but will it be too late?,” BioSpace.com, November 11, 2020, biospace.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  have produced positive data or received Emergency Use Authorization. The emerging data from these treatments suggest they have the potential to materially reduce hospitalizations and deaths for cases that do occur, accelerating a transition toward normalcy. </li>
    <li><em>New cases and deaths are lower—but still high. </em>New cases, hospitalizations, and deaths have dropped dramatically—by 79 percent and 89 percent, respectively, in the United States and the United Kingdom from the January peak, as of March 15.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c6bdd811-63cb-46be-b013-3e94dc6e1ace"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">118</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c6bdd811-63cb-46be-b013-3e94dc6e1ace" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jordan Allen et al., “Coronavirus in the U.S.: Latest map and case count,” <em>New York Times,</em> updated March 18, 2021, nytimes.com. Based on seven-day averages of cases.</span></span></span></a></span>  This trajectory has amplified discussions of a transition toward normalcy in both countries. The bend in the curve is fragile, however. Much of the decline in Europe has followed strict lockdowns; but lockdowns and other nonpharmaceutical interventions  are still confoundingly difficult to get right, and even now, multiple European countries are experiencing upward case trends. And US deaths are still averaging 1,000 per day, many times higher than average daily flu deaths.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7727f947-40dd-49f9-87d0-6adc4c297908"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">119</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7727f947-40dd-49f9-87d0-6adc4c297908" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“COVID data tracker,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, last accessed March 20, 2021, cdc.gov; “Weekly U.S. influenza surveillance report,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, last reviewed March 19, 2021, cdc.gov.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>It is increasingly clear that more infectious variants of concern</em><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8979c901-d52e-4852-b0f0-58b28ec4f7d0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">120</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8979c901-d52e-4852-b0f0-58b28ec4f7d0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“SARS-CoV-2 variants,” Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, last updated March 16, 2021, cdc.gov.</span></span></span></a></span><em>  may drive a new wave of cases in the coming months. </em>The United Kingdom is in a relatively favorable position; cases are declining in spite of the high prevalence of the B.1.1.7 variant, suggesting that the country has a demonstrable ability to control the spread of more infectious variants. In contrast, the United States and parts of the European Union appear to have an increasing prevalence of B.1.1.7.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2ab8b2ba-0064-463e-8a4f-af204db0fab8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">121</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2ab8b2ba-0064-463e-8a4f-af204db0fab8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Risk assessment: SARS-CoV-2 – increased circulation of variants of concern and vaccine rollout in the EU/EEA, 14th update,</em> European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), February 2021, ecdc.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span>  The potential for a variant-driven wave of US cases and ongoing spread in Europe in the coming months is real.</li>
    <li><em>Variants may also reduce vaccine efficacy or enable reinfection.</em> Data from the AstraZeneca vaccine trial in South Africa highlight the potential for variants such as B.1.351 and P.1 to reduce the efficacy of vaccines.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9020270a-ac42-4ca8-a3e9-c58913c0a6a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">122</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9020270a-ac42-4ca8-a3e9-c58913c0a6a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Shabhir A. Mahdi et al., “Efficacy of the ChAdOx1 nCoV-19 Covid-19 vaccine against the B.1.351 variant,” <em>The New England Journal of Medicine,</em> March 16, 2021, nejm.org.  </span></span></span></a></span> Other vaccine data, including those from Novavax and Johnson & Johnson, show a more modest reduction in efficacy, especially against severe disease caused by these variants.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4d8f217-b846-42d3-a54e-696b18ca577d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">123</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4d8f217-b846-42d3-a54e-696b18ca577d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Novavax COVID-19 vaccine demonstrates 89.3% efficacy in UK Phase 3 trial,” Novavax, January 28, 2021, ir.novavax.com; Carl Zimmer, Noah Weiland, and Sharon LaFraniere, “New analyses show Johnson & Johnson’s one-dose vaccine works well,” <em>New York Times</em>, February 24, 2021, nytimes.com.</span></span></span></a></span> There is also early evidence of mutations arising independently in the United States that may reduce the efficacy of vaccines.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bfa6359d-2b9b-42a4-9596-c2dc56e71459"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">124</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bfa6359d-2b9b-42a4-9596-c2dc56e71459" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eyewitness News, “Coronavirus vaccine updates: Scientists concerned over New York's ‘escape variant’,” ABC, Inc., WABC-TV New York, March 16, 2021, abc7ny.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  These variants also appear to be more infectious than the original wild-type strain. These initial findings are based on very small sample sizes and may change as more information becomes available; we still do not know the impact of vaccines against severe disease from these strains. But if these results hold up, the spread of strains against which existing vaccines are substantially less effective would be a significant risk to lives and could delay the end of the pandemic.</li>
</ol>
<p>What’s the net impact of all these developments? The data continue to indicate, as stated in our earlier perspectives, that a significant transition toward UK and US normalcy will occur in the second quarter of 2021, although the potential for a variant-driven wave in the United States is real and would blunt the transition (Exhibit 1). Potential herd-immunity timelines are bifurcating as a result of growth in variants that may reduce vaccine efficacy. If the variants turn out to be a minor factor (they only reduce vaccine efficacy modestly, or they don’t spread widely), then herd immunity in the second half of the year is likely for both countries—and is more likely in the third quarter than the fourth. However, if the impact of these variants is significant, we could see timelines significantly prolonging into late 2021 or beyond.</p>

<h3>How does this vary by geography?</h3>
<p>Most of our analysis in this series has focused on the United Kingdom and the United States, which continue to move down a similar path. The end of Europe’s pandemic may come somewhat later, and other countries’ outlooks will depend on several variables.  </p>
<p><strong><em>European Union.</em></strong> Here, as in other regions, the timing of access to vaccines will be the biggest driver of the end of the pandemic. Levels of natural immunity from prior infection vary within the European Union but are generally in the same range as in the United Kingdom and the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e3c69070-4787-4534-83fa-4f68e90c1bca"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">125</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e3c69070-4787-4534-83fa-4f68e90c1bca" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">SeroTracker, last accessed March 15, 2021, serotracker.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  Seasonality is likely to work in similar ways. And public interest in vaccination appears to be similar too, even in countries such as France, where interest in vaccination was significantly lower than in other countries in the region but may now be improving.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d29faf48-69d4-459e-82f8-b93df2cdef39"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">126</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d29faf48-69d4-459e-82f8-b93df2cdef39" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Global attitudes: COVID-19 vaccines,” Ipsos, February 9, 2021, ipsos.com; Yasmeen Serhan, “The vaccine-hesitant man of Europe,” <em>The Atlantic</em>, March 18, 2021, theatlantic.com. </span></span></span></a></span>  The prevalence of the more infectious B.1.1.7 variant varies by country; most countries with cases are between the high UK levels and lower US levels.</p>
<p>Exhibit 2 lays out the likely timing of vaccine availability in the European Union. Broadly speaking, availability will be similar to that of the United Kingdom and the United States, but EU countries may need to wait a few months longer to vaccinate all adults. Please note that this would be subject to change and further delay if the Oxford–AstraZeneca vaccine remains suspended in multiple countries following concerns about blood clots; WHO has confirmed its continued support of the vaccine.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d0abd58-9abb-4f56-99e0-9f52d1e7fb2d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">127</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d0abd58-9abb-4f56-99e0-9f52d1e7fb2d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“WHO statement on AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine safety signals,” WHO, March 17, 2021, who.int.</span></span></span></a></span> </p>
