If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Given that sufficient vaccine doses are available to vaccinate the highest-risk populations in the coming months, we expect to see the EU transition to normalcy during the second quarter of the year, although the start of this transition may be delayed until late in the quarter by a new wave of cases in some countries. A key difference for the European Union, as compared with the United Kingdom and the United States: herd immunity is more likely in the fourth quarter than the third quarter, given the likely timeline of vaccine delivery (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/mar%202021/svgz-pandemicendmarchupdate-ex3-rev.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Vaccines should be available for most adults in the European Union, United Kingdom, and United States, but timing varies." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/mar%202021/svgz-pandemicendmarchupdate-ex3-rev.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p><strong><em>Rest of the world. </em></strong>While the European Union, the United Kingdom, and the United States have had broadly similar COVID-19 experiences, other parts of the world look very different. Countries like New Zealand have avoided significant COVID-19-associated mortality but appear to be further from herd immunity because so few New Zealanders have infection-driven immunity to SARS-CoV-2. On the other hand, if vaccine uptake is fast, New Zealand might achieve a longer-lasting vaccine-based herd immunity. A second factor is seasonality: the timing of seasonality-driven changes will be different in tropical locations and the Southern Hemisphere. A third is demographics: while the younger populations of many lower-income countries have led to lower COVID-19-associated mortality, they also make it harder for adult-only vaccination programs to drive herd immunity. And perhaps most importantly for timelines, access to vaccines is unequal. While COVAX and other access initiatives are working to close the gap, many low-income countries may not receive enough doses to vaccinate all adults until well into 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e9038b90-cd2e-435e-84ff-d34088ffa930"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">128</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e9038b90-cd2e-435e-84ff-d34088ffa930" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“More than 85 poor countries will not have widespread access to coronavirus vaccines before 2023,” Economist Intelligence Unit, January 27, 2021, eiu.com.</span></span></span></a></span>  The world is on pace to manufacture enough <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world">doses for 80 percent of the global population</a>—or close to 100 percent of the adult population—by the end of 2021, but the distribution of these doses may continue to be asymmetric.</p>
<p>Exhibit 4 provides a global view of seven factors that are likely to drive herd-immunity timelines for the rest of the world. These factors include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Population vaccinated—the proportion of people who have received the vaccine so far</li>
    <li>Vaccine courses secured—the additional supplies for which a country has contracted</li>
    <li>Supply-chain readiness</li>
    <li>Consumer vaccine sentiment—the public’s willingness to be vaccinated</li>
    <li>Population under 19 years of age—a greater proportion of children makes a transition toward normalcy easier to achieve but herd immunity more difficult</li>
    <li>Natural immunity, or the rate of prior COVID-19 infection—higher <em>historical </em>infection rates decrease the vaccination rate needed to achieve herd immunity</li>
    <li>Prevalence of variants of concern</li>
</ul>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/mar%202021/svgz-pandemicendmarchupdate-ex4-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/mar%202021/svgz-pandemicendmarchupdate-ex4-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h3>Risks to herd immunity</h3>
<p>Herd immunity requires that enough people be simultaneously immune to SARS-CoV-2 to prevent widespread ongoing transmission. While data indicate that the most likely scenario is to reach this state on the timelines described above, five risks could delay progress.</p>
<p>First, vaccine adoption may prove lower than expected. That could happen if a real or perceived safety issue increases hesitancy or if younger populations see little reason to be vaccinated once older cohorts are protected and a transition toward normalcy is well underway. Second, herd immunity relies on the efficacy of vaccines at reducing transmission (rather than the usually reported efficacy at preventing disease in the vaccinated person). While initial data suggest that COVID-19 vaccines do block significant transmission,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="aec46a5e-90d0-4e22-8bd8-af7f1d7fb17b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">129</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="aec46a5e-90d0-4e22-8bd8-af7f1d7fb17b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Smriti Mallapaty, “Can COVID vaccines stop transmission? Scientists race to find answers,” <em>Nature</em>, February 19, 2021, nature.com. </span></span></span></a></span>  the efficacy rate may not prove high enough to drive herd immunity. Third, the duration of vaccine-mediated immunity may prove shorter than anticipated, making it hard to reach the necessary threshold for simultaneous immunity. Fourth, supply-chain disruptions and delays are real, and could produce supply shocks and interfere with timelines. Fifth, and most concerning, variants that reduce the efficacy of vaccines or the benefits of natural immunity may spread widely. Some initial data offer concerning evidence that B.1.351 and P.1 may be examples of such variants, although recent Novavax data (with a small sample size) offer some reassurance that its vaccine is effective against severe disease caused by B1.351.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d6052d7f-0221-4474-95fa-6b28e90b6d5c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">130</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d6052d7f-0221-4474-95fa-6b28e90b6d5c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lee Landenberger, “Novavax’s COVID-19 vaccine shows 100% protection against severe disease,” March 12, 2021, bioworld.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, limited data from the Pfizer-BioNTech and AstraZeneca vaccines show evidence of some protection against P.1.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="90c88748-fa8e-447d-a166-c0c0f3818289"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">131</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="90c88748-fa8e-447d-a166-c0c0f3818289" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Existing vaccines may protect against the Brazilian coronavirus variant,” University of Oxford, March 18, 2021, ox.ac.uk.</span></span></span></a></span><strong>   </strong></p>
<p>These five factors combined mean that there is still a meaningful chance that herd immunity is not reached in the medium term.</p>
<h3>From theory to practice: What the ‘end’ might look like</h3>
<p>The pandemic’s two endpoints, a transition toward normalcy and herd immunity, may look different in different places. As the name implies, a transition will include a series of steps that will gradually normalize aspects of social and economic life. The order and pace of these steps will vary by geography. Not everyone will immediately resume all of their prepandemic activities; rather, there will be a noticeable shift toward more of them. Steps may include a return to fully in-classroom education, fewer restrictions on the operations of bars and restaurants, more gatherings with larger groups of people, the reopening of offices, and fewer prohibitions on interregional or international travel. The United Kingdom’s plan for reopening provides an example of the stepwise manner in which a transition to normalcy is likely to occur.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ba378b7e-7b39-4849-b28f-d32d6c56d9a4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">132</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ba378b7e-7b39-4849-b28f-d32d6c56d9a4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Lockdown: Boris Johnson unveils plan to end England restrictions by 21 June,” February 22, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Herd immunity will represent a more definitive end to the pandemic. Isolated cases may still occur—indeed, the virus may continue to circulate for one or more quarters after herd immunity is reached. But with herd immunity, population-wide public-health measures can be phased out. As populations get closer to this state, it may be helpful to introduce some nuance to what we mean by the term.</p>
<ol>
    <li><em>Nationwide herd immunity. </em>The full population is well protected so that the country experiences, at most, occasional small flare-ups of disease. This scenario is most likely in smaller countries where immunity to COVID-19 can become uniformly high.</li>
    <li><em>Regional herd immunity.</em> Some regions, states, or cities are well protected, while others experience ongoing outbreaks of COVID-19. In large, diverse countries like the United States, this situation is especially easy to imagine.</li>
    <li><em>Temporary herd immunity.</em> A population or region achieves herd immunity for some period, but as variants are introduced, against which prior immunity is less effective, a new wave of cases is launched. Another potential trigger for such a wave could come as immunity (particularly natural immunity) wanes. As the number of new cases of COVID-19 falls globally, the rate of emergence of important variants should also decrease, but some risk will remain.</li>
    <li><em>Endemicity. </em>A region fails to achieve herd immunity. Endemicity is most likely in places where vaccine access is limited, where few people choose to be vaccinated, if the duration of immunity is short, or variants that reduce vaccine efficacy are common and widespread. Endemicity might include cyclic, seasonal waves of disease, broadly similar to the flu, or a multiyear cycle of resurgence.</li>
</ol>
<p>The next few years are likely to see a combination of some or all of these options around the world. Given the likely timing of herd immunity in various geographies and the uncertain duration of protection from vaccines (both duration of immune response and efficacy versus new variants), it is likely that some measures such as booster vaccines are likely to be required indefinitely. Herd immunity is not the same as eradication. SARS-CoV-2 will continue to exist. Even when a country reaches herd immunity, ongoing surveillance, booster vaccines, and potentially other measures may be needed.</p>
<hr>
<p>A year ago, the world was coming to terms with a long, difficult journey ahead. Twelve months later, the end of the pandemic is in sight for some parts of the world. It’s much too soon to declare victory, however. We hope that our perspectives prove useful to leaders as they set policy and strategy; we will continue to update the series.</p>

<p><strong>About the authors</strong></p>
<p><strong><a href="/our-people/sarun-charumilind">Sarun Charumilind</a></strong> and <strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-lamb">Jessica Lamb</a></strong> are both partners in McKinsey’s Philadelphia office, <strong><a href="/our-people/matt-craven">Matt Craven</a></strong> is a partner in the Silicon Valley office, <strong><a href="/our-people/adam-sabow">Adam Sabow</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Chicago office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/matt-wilson">Matt Wilson</a></strong> is a senior partner in the New York office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Xavier Azcue for his contributions to this article.</p>

<p>This article was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.</p>
<hr>
<br>
<br>
<h2>January 20, 2021</h2>
<h4>This article updates our earlier perspectives on when the coronavirus pandemic will end. Transition toward normalcy in the United States remains most likely in the second quarter of 2021 and herd immunity in the third and fourth quarters, but the emergence of new strains and a slow start to vaccine rollout raise real risks to both timelines. We also add a perspective for the United Kingdom.</h4>
<p><strong>The past five weeks</strong> have brought an array of conflicting news on the COVID-19 pandemic, affecting our estimates about when the coronavirus pandemic will end. Margaret Keenan, a British nonagenarian, made history on December 8 by becoming the first person to receive the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for SARS-CoV-2 outside a clinical trial.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7b121fc1-b995-4072-be85-a68c5ed10f5b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">133</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7b121fc1-b995-4072-be85-a68c5ed10f5b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Covid-19 vaccine: First person receives Pfizer jab in UK,” BBC, December 8, 2020, bbc.com/news.</span></span></span></a></span> Since then, several other vaccines have been authorized for use around the world. Sufficient doses are likely to be available to vaccinate high-risk populations in the United States in the first half of 2021. In parallel, however, more-infectious strains of the virus have been detected in South Africa, the United Kingdom, and elsewhere and have spread to an increasing number of countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45ca7974-466e-4c3b-b397-ade0891af27b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">134</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45ca7974-466e-4c3b-b397-ade0891af27b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Miriam Berger, “U.K. variant continues to spread around the world as coronavirus pandemic enters 2021,” <em>Washington Post</em>, January 2, 2021, washingtonpost.com.</span></span></span></a></span> And the initial rollout of vaccines has been slower than hoped in many places.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36a7a603-f46c-4751-ac1e-badfa9792b52"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">135</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36a7a603-f46c-4751-ac1e-badfa9792b52" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Michelle R. Smith, “Governors scramble to speed vaccine effort after slow start,” <em>Associated Press</em>, January 6, 2021, apnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While the United States could still achieve herd immunity in the third or fourth quarter of 2021 (in line with the peak probability in our previous estimates), the emergence of more-infectious variants of SARS-CoV-2 increases the risk that this milestone will not be achieved until later. More-infectious viruses require that a higher percentage of people be simultaneously immune to reach herd immunity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ee116d4-3840-4791-87f5-cacb37b9515a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">136</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ee116d4-3840-4791-87f5-cacb37b9515a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ken Eames, Paul Fine, and David L. Heymann, ‘‘‘Herd immunity’: A rough guide,” <em>Clinical Infectious Diseases</em>, 2011, Volume 52, Number 7, pp. 911–6, academic.oup.com.</span></span></span></a></span> While a more infectious variant likely means more people are acquiring natural immunity through infection (despite ongoing efforts to minimize new cases), the net impact of more-infectious strains is likely to be that a higher portion of the population needs to be vaccinated, which may take more time.</p>
<p>We still believe that the United States can transition toward normalcy during the second quarter of 2021, but the same risks also threaten this timeline. A transition toward normalcy would be driven by a combination of seasonality aiding a decline in cases and early vaccine doses helping reduce mortality by protecting those at greatest risk of serious illness. As COVID-19’s impact on health wanes, we are likely to see greater normalization of social and economic life. Data on the availability of vaccine doses in the United States increase confidence that this is possible, but the slow start to the vaccine rollout reinforces that success is by no means guaranteed.</p>
<p>This article describes “most likely” timelines for when the coronavirus pandemic will end. It is now harder to imagine the United States or United Kingdom transitioning to normalcy before second quarter 2021 or reaching herd immunity before third quarter 2021. But a number of other factors could delay the timelines beyond those described, including unexpected safety issues emerging with early vaccines, significant manufacturing or supply-chain delays, continued slow adoption, further mutation, or a shorter-than-anticipated duration of vaccine-conferred immunity. Herd immunity will also require vaccines to be effective in reducing transmission of SARS-CoV-2, not just in protecting vaccinated individuals from getting sick. This is likely, but has not yet been proven at scale.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2a7e1bf1-a8e1-4e2f-ae17-d3a6f4a9a38e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">137</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2a7e1bf1-a8e1-4e2f-ae17-d3a6f4a9a38e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sabin Russell, “Vaccines stop COVID-19 symptoms, but do they stop transmission?,” <em>Fred Hutch News Service</em>, December 16, 2020, fredhutch.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Tania Adam webinar" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/jan%202021/tania-adam-webinar-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>WATCH</div></h3><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-7"><p><div>A McKinsey Live event on ‘COVID-19 vaccines are here. What does that mean for your organization?’</div></p></div></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Click here</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<h3>Herd immunity</h3>
<h4>More-infectious strains raise the bar</h4>
<p>Herd immunity to a pathogen is achieved when a sufficient portion of a population is simultaneously immune to prevent sustained transmission. The threshold to achieve it is governed by a number of factors, including the transmissibility of the disease.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="28b8e7aa-fd13-4881-9ac1-d1653c992f69"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">138</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="28b8e7aa-fd13-4881-9ac1-d1653c992f69" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eames, Fine, and Heymann, ‘‘‘Herd immunity’: A rough guide,” pp. 911–6.</span></span></span></a></span> More-infectious strains of SARS-CoV-2 therefore raise the bar on herd immunity. The virus has been mutating since it was identified a year ago. The concerning development in recent weeks has been the confirmation of new strains in South Africa, the United Kingdom, and elsewhere that combine multiple mutations and have different profiles. While data are still emerging, initial estimates suggest that the transmissibility rate of the UK strain is 40 to 80 percent higher than that of the original SARS-CoV-2 strain, and that transmission rates could be higher among children too.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1e1bc79f-06ef-4590-8377-caeec49d33c0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">139</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1e1bc79f-06ef-4590-8377-caeec49d33c0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Erik Volz et al., <em>Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 Lineage B.1.1.7 in England: Insights from linking epidemiological and genetic data</em>, Imperial College London, December 2020, imperial.ac.uk.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b577bb6f-fe0e-4dc6-b59a-975f774f5554"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">140</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b577bb6f-fe0e-4dc6-b59a-975f774f5554" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nicholas Davies et al., <em>Estimated transmissibility and severity of novel SARS-CoV-2 Variant of Concern 202012/01 in England</em>, Centre for Mathematical Modelling of Infectious Diseases, December 2020, cmmid.github.io.</span></span></span></a></span> There is no evidence of higher case fatality with either new strain, but there are fears that new strains may affect how antibodies bind to the virus and may reduce the efficacy of vaccines or antibody treatments developed over the past few months. More data are likely to emerge on this in the weeks ahead.</p>
<p>If these strains become dominant, they may cause a material delay in reaching herd immunity. While many people are acquiring natural immunity through infection, variants with enhanced transmissibility, if they predominate among all strains, could increase the proportion of people who need to be simultaneously immune to achieve herd immunity by ten to 20 percentage points, and increase vaccine coverage levels needed to 65 to 80 percent of the population (or 78 to 95 percent of those over 12 years old).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="15ac494b-b2f1-4171-ad83-021cc84f1377"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">141</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="15ac494b-b2f1-4171-ad83-021cc84f1377" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on a reproduction number (R0) of 2.4 for the original strain and assuming that the herd immunity threshold can be approximated using the formula 1- (1/R0). For more, see Eames, Fine, and Heymann, ‘‘‘Herd immunity’: A rough guide,” pp. 911–6. Estimates of increased vaccine coverage needed are based on R0 = 3.36-4.32, which is 40–80% greater than R0 of 2.4.</span></span></span></a></span> More detail is shown in Exhibit 1 below.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Vaccinating more people is a nonlinear challenge. Consumer surveys suggest that a portion of the population is <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-vaccines-meet-100-million-uncertain-americans">cautious about vaccination</a>. Increasing coverage from 70 to 80 percent is therefore harder than increasing from 60 to 70 percent. Because more-transmissible variants raise herd-immunity thresholds, there will also be less tolerance for low vaccine effectiveness. For example, with a variant that is 40 to 80 percent more transmissible, vaccine efficacy of 90 percent would require 83 to 100 percent of those over 12 to be vaccinated; efficacy of anything less than 75 percent would make herd immunity likely unachievable through vaccination of only those over 12.</p>
<p>While the variant of concern appears to be most widespread in the United Kingdom, it has been detected in over 30 countries, many of which (including the United States) have limited capacity for genetic sequencing. As a result, we may be significantly underestimating its spread.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cb828e06-36a4-4d10-a0f9-47ab9ec04c7a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">142</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cb828e06-36a4-4d10-a0f9-47ab9ec04c7a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Miriam Berger, “U.K. variant continues to spread around the world as coronavirus pandemic enters 2021,” <em>Washington Post</em>, Jan 2, 2021, washingtonpost.com.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ab8b67e5-729e-4145-938e-c31baed1941f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">143</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ab8b67e5-729e-4145-938e-c31baed1941f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Carl Zimmer, “U.S. is blind to contagious new virus variant, scientists warn,” <em>New York Times</em>, January 6, 2021, nytimes.com.</span></span></span></a></span> The strain is likely to continue spreading in the coming months, propelled by its reproductive advantage over the original. This appears to have occurred in southern England over the past few months. If new strains predominate, they could lead to a longer timeline to herd immunity.</p>
<h4>Vaccine rollout: A slow start, but there is still time to improve</h4>
<p>The speed of COVID-19 vaccine development has been an unqualified success. The approval, in at least one country, of vaccines made by Pfizer and BioNTech, Moderna, Oxford and AstraZeneca, Sinopharm, Serum Institute, Bharat Biotech, Gamaleya, and others within a year of viral sequencing smashed all records for development timelines. But rollout is off to a slow start. While countries such as Israel have shown what is possible, the United States has fallen behind its targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="349552b4-59ed-44cf-a61e-b22718c541a9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">144</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="349552b4-59ed-44cf-a61e-b22718c541a9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Coronavirus: Israel leads vaccine race with 12% given jab,” <em>BBC</em>, January 3, 2021, bbc.com.</span></span></span></a></span><span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6259442c-f393-4a8b-805f-33acf806db03"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">145</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6259442c-f393-4a8b-805f-33acf806db03" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Michelle R. Smith, “Governors scramble to speed vaccine effort after slow start,” <em>Associated Press</em>, January 6, 2021, apnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span> It is still early days, and there is time to accelerate, but there is little margin for error if the United States is to achieve herd immunity in third quarter 2021. In addition, not all regions are adhering closely to manufacturer dosing protocols—for example, delaying second doses or giving a first dose from one manufacturer followed by a second from another—and the impact of that is unclear. These approaches could reduce mortality in the short term by broadening access, but they could also delay herd immunity if, for example, a delayed second dose reduces efficacy. It’s also possible that once most people in the highest-risk groups have received vaccinations, the pace of vaccination will slow if lower-risk groups do not embrace the opportunity.</p>
<p>We believe that herd immunity in the United States is still most likely in third or fourth quarter 2021, but that the chance of delay until first quarter 2022 or beyond has increased (Exhibit 2). There is relatively little chance of achieving herd immunity before then. Even later herd immunity remains possible if other challenges arise, especially vaccine safety concerns or ambivalence to vaccination following a transition toward normalcy. This potential delay represents a call to action for policy makers, both in terms of the pace of the vaccine rollout and how new strains are managed.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/jan%202021/svgz-pandemicend-jan2021-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Probability of herd immunity to COVID-19 for the United Kingdom and United States, by date; factors affecting the date (chart)" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/jan%202021/svgz-pandemicend-jan2021-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only"><h2>More-transmissible variants and slower initial vaccine rollout increase downside risk to the Q3–Q4 2021 timeline to achieve herd immunity.</h2>

<h3>Chart: Probability of herd immunity<sup>1</sup> to COVID-19 pandemic for the United Kingdom and United States<sup>2</sup> by quarter (illustrative)</h3>

<p>Two skewed bell curves estimate when herd immunity will occur.</p>

<ul>
  <li>11/23/20 estimate. From Q4 2020 to Q1 2021 the probability of herd immunity is negligible. The curve rises sharply from Q1 2021 to a peak between Q3 and Q4 2021. The long tail of the curve shows falling probabilities to Q3 2023 and beyond.</li>
  <li>1/15/21 estimate. The start, peak, and tail of this curve are almost the same as the previous one. A flatter curve indicates herd immunity will probably occur one month later.</li>
</ul>

<h3>Early herd immunity if:</h3>
<ul>
  <li>Vaccine rollout and adoption are faster than expected</li>
  <li>Natural immunity is significantly higher than realized</li>
  <li>More-transmissible variants lead to higher rates of natural immunity</li>
</ul>
<h3>Peak probability of herd immunity driven by:</h3>
<ul>
  <li>US Biologics License Applications (BLA) with full approval by March/April 2021 or earlier</li>
  <li>Approximately 3–9 months for manufacturing, distribution, and sufficient adoption to reach herd immunity</li>
</ul>
<h3>Later herd immunity if one or more of the following occur:</h3>
<ul>
  <li>Safety issues delay BLA</li>
  <li>Manufacturing/supply-chain issues slow rollout</li>
  <li>More-infectious variants raise the threshold for achieving herd immunity</li>
  <li>Adoption is slower than anticipated</li>
  <li>Duration of immunity is short</li>
  <li>Vaccine prevents disease progression but does not meaningfully reduce transmission</li>
</ul>

<h3>Notes</h3>
<p><sup>1</sup>Herd immunity is achieved when a sufficient portion of a population is simultaneously immune to prevent sustained transmission. At this point, significant, ongoing public-health measures are not needed to prevent future spikes in disease and mortality (this might be achieved while there are still a number of people in particular communities who still have the disease, as is the case with measles).</p>
<p><sup>2</sup>Timeline to functional end is likely to vary somewhat based on geography.</p>
<p>McKinsey & Company</p>
</div></div>
<h4>Increasing recognition of medium-term endemicity
</h4>
<p>While many parts of the world are expected to reach herd immunity against COVID-19, there is increasing consensus that globally, SARS-CoV-2 is likely to remain endemic in the medium term. David Heymann, the chairman of the World Health Organization’s Strategic and Technical Advisory Group for Infectious Hazards, noted in December that endemicity may be the “destiny” of this virus.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="093a26c1-0e19-46a8-acd2-17da982f3fa8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">146</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="093a26c1-0e19-46a8-acd2-17da982f3fa8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Melissa Davey, “WHO warns Covid-19 pandemic is ‘not necessarily the big one,’” <em>Guardian</em>, December 29, 2020, theguardian.com.</span></span></span></a></span> This might make COVID-19 analogous to measles—a disease that causes intermittent, limited outbreaks in countries with well-developed vaccination programs but significant ongoing disease in parts of the world where access to vaccines is more limited. It is also possible that COVID-19 will be seasonal, with predictable annual peaks in parts of the world where it is endemic.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="955c2009-a21c-44c5-9d5a-82a6e1091a40"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">147</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="955c2009-a21c-44c5-9d5a-82a6e1091a40" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Apoorva Mandavilli, “The future of the coronavirus? An annoying childhood infection,” <em>New York Times</em>, January 12, 2021, nytimes.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Transition toward normalcy</h3>
<p>A transition toward normalcy will occur when COVID-19 mortality falls and the disease is de-exceptionalized in society. COVID-19 will not disappear during this transition, but will become a more normal part of the baseline disease burden in society (like flu, for example), rather than a special threat requiring exceptional societal response. During this transition, controlling the spread of SARS-CoV-2 will still require public-health measures (such as continued COVID-19 testing and mask use in many settings), but mortality will fall significantly, allowing greater normalization of business and social activities. This will be driven by a combination of early vaccine rollout (which, being directed first at those at greatest risk, should reduce deaths faster than cases), seasonality, increasing natural immunity, and stronger public-health response.</p>
<p>Increasing clarity on the availability of vaccine doses during the first half of 2021 in the United States improves the odds of an early transition toward normalcy. As Exhibit 3 shows, Pfizer and Moderna are expected to deliver sufficient vaccine doses to vaccinate all high-risk Americans during the first half of the year. This does not account for other vaccines that are likely to become available, including those approved in other markets (for example, Oxford-AstraZeneca) or others that are likely to report clinical trial data in the first quarter of 2021 (including Johnson & Johnson and Novavax). Older people are generally more willing to be vaccinated than the general population. However, slow initial rollout of the vaccines and the spread of more infectious variants increase the risk that significant mortality continues in the second quarter, blunting a transition to normalcy.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/jan%202021/svgz-pandemicend-jan2021-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="In the United States, doses committed by Pfizer and Moderna by July 31, 2021 are approximately enough for population in phases 1a&ndash;c (chart)" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare%20systems%20and%20services/our%20insights/when%20will%20the%20covid%2019%20pandemic%20end/jan%202021/svgz-pandemicend-jan2021-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only"><h2>In the United States, doses committed by Pfizer and Moderna by July 31 are approximately enough for population in phases 1a–c.</h2>

<h3>Notes</h3>
<p><sup>1</sup>Two doses needed per person.</p>

<p>Taking these variables into account, we still believe that a transition toward normalcy is likely during second quarter for the United States, but that downside risks have increased. If early vaccine doses reach a significant percentage of high-risk elderly individuals by the end of quarter one, the combination of protecting these groups and the arrival of spring in the northern hemisphere should improve the situation compared with where the United States is now. Depending on vaccination progress over the summer (whether the United States is on the earlier or later end of the herd immunity window), there may be a smaller fall wave of disease in third to fourth quarter 2021.</p>
<p>While the potential for a transition toward normalcy in just a few months is encouraging, many signs suggest that the next six to eight weeks will be difficult. Case and death numbers are at or near all-time highs in many locations, new variants may accelerate short-term transmission, and vaccine rollout has not yet proceeded far enough to protect much of the population. Strong public-health measures will remain critical to saving lives during this period.</p>
<h3>Timeline for the United Kingdom</h3>
<p>We see similar dynamics in the United Kingdom. Three factors lead us to believe that timelines for herd immunity and transition toward normalcy in the United Kingdom will be similar to those in the United States. First, access to vaccines is sufficient to immunize a large percentage of both the US and UK populations during 2021. Second, public willingness to be vaccinated is generally similar between the two countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0f589c2c-1efd-4627-bc89-e5e0f47e5c66"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">148</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0f589c2c-1efd-4627-bc89-e5e0f47e5c66" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jeffrey V. Lazarus et al., “A global survey of potential acceptance of a COVID-19 vaccine,” <em>Nature Medicine</em>, 2020, nature.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Third, the fraction of US and UK residents who already have natural immunity from prior infection is in the same range (with significant variability among regions within countries).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2dd887be-fff8-4236-ace2-9f5f67b5b4bf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">149</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2dd887be-fff8-4236-ace2-9f5f67b5b4bf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“SeroTracker,” Public Health Agency of Canada, accessed 1/12/21, serotracker.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The variant of concern represents a potential source of difference. While it is known to be highly prevalent in the United Kingdom and present in the United States, there is a significant chance that it will predominate throughout the United States over the coming months. All else being equal, countries with a higher proportion of more-infectious variants—assuming they increase public-health measures to handle them—are likely to achieve herd immunity later.</p>
<p>We will add a perspective for other parts of the world, including the rest of Western Europe, in future updates to this article.</p>
<hr>
<p>Twelve months ago, most people weren’t thinking about COVID-19. Today, much of the world is intensely focused on it, but we can reasonably expect the imminent threat to abate. Much work remains to be done. In the short term, public-health measures can help control the pandemic, but even when herd immunity is achieved, managing the risk of COVID-19 will require monitoring, potential revaccination, and treatment of isolated cases. Every country has its own COVID-19 story, but those stories will eventually reach some kind of ending.</p>

<hr>
<p><strong>About the authors</strong></p>
<p><strong><a href="/our-people/sarun-charumilind">Sarun Charumilind</a></strong> and <strong><a href="/our-people/jessica-lamb">Jessica Lamb</a></strong> are both partners in McKinsey’s Philadelphia office, <strong><a href="/our-people/matt-craven">Matt Craven</a></strong> is a partner in the Silicon Valley office, <strong><a href="/our-people/adam-sabow">Adam Sabow</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Chicago office, and <strong><a href="/our-people/matt-wilson">Matt Wilson</a></strong> is a senior partner in the New York office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Xavier Azcue, Brian Hencke, David Meredith, Michalis Michaelides, Anthony Ramirez, Virginia Simmons, Konstantinos Tsakalis, and Lieven Van der Veken for their contributions to this article.</p>
<hr>
<br>
<br>
<h2>November 23, 2020</h2>
<h4>Our November 23 update takes on the questions raised by recent news: When will vaccines be available? And is the end of COVID-19 nearer?</h4>
<p><strong>Since we published <a href="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/healthcare systems and services/our insights/when will the covid 19 pandemic end/sep 2020/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end-final.pdf">our first outlook</a>,</strong> on September 21st, the COVID-19 pandemic has raged on, with more than 25 million additional cases and more than 400,000 additional deaths. While the situation looks somewhat better in parts of the Southern Hemisphere, much of Europe and North America is in the midst of a “fall wave,” with the prospect of a difficult winter ahead. Yet the past two weeks have brought renewed hope, headlined by final data from the Pfizer/BioNTech<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="643d27de-72ad-43b6-8339-89972b892c64"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">150</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="643d27de-72ad-43b6-8339-89972b892c64" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Pfizer and BioNTech conclude Phase 3 study of COVID-19 vaccine candidate, meeting all primary efficacy endpoints,” Pfizer, November 18, 2020, pfizer.com.</span></span></span></a></span> vaccine trial and interim data from the Moderna trial, both showing efficacy of approximately 95 percent<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ed6ac8a4-0df0-4db7-93ca-466b14d61286"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">151</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ed6ac8a4-0df0-4db7-93ca-466b14d61286" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Moderna’s COVID-19 vaccine candidate meets its primary efficacy endpoint in the first interim analysis of the Phase 3 COVE study, Moderna, November 16, 2020, modernatx.com.</span></span></span></a></span>; and progress on therapeutics. Is an earlier end to the pandemic now more likely? </p>
<p>The short answer is that the latest developments serve mainly to reduce the uncertainty of the timeline (Exhibit 1). The positive readouts from the vaccine trials mean that the United States will most likely reach an epidemiological end to the pandemic (herd immunity) in Q3 or Q4 2021. An earlier timeline to reach herd immunity—for example, Q1/Q2 of 2021—is now less likely, as is a later timeline (2022). If we are able to pair these vaccines with more effective implementation of public-health measures and effective scale-up of new treatments and diagnostics, alongside the benefits of seasonality, we may also be able to reduce mortality enough in Q2 to enable the United States to transition toward normalcy. (See sidebar “Two endpoints” for our definitions.)</p>
